options.text: At the junction of the occlusion.

options.text: The cold front becomes a front aloft.
The warm front overtakes the cold front.
The warm front becomes a front aloft.

variant.question: Occlusions are formed when...

options.text: a cold front crosses a mountain ridge
a warm front crosses a mountain ridge

variant.question: An occlusion is called a warm occlusion when the cold air:

options.text: at the rear of the occlusion is less cold than the cold air ahead, with the warm air at a higher altitude.
at the rear of the occlusion is colder than the cold air ahead, with the warm air at a higher altitude.
ahead of the surface position of the occlusion is only at a higher altitude.
at the rear of the occlusion is colder than the cold air ahead.

variant.question: What type of front / occlusion usually moves the fastest?
Describe a cold occlusion at a polar front depression:

options.text: the air ahead of the warm front is warmer than the air behind the cold front.
both, the air ahead of the warm front and the air behind the cold front are of approximately the same temperature.
the air ahead of the warm front is colder than the air behind the cold front.
the air behind the cold front is less cold than the air ahead of the warm front.

variant.question: An 'OCCLUSION' forms when

options.text: a cold front catches up with a warm front.
the warm air displaces cold air.
the cold air displaces warm air.

variant.question: Which of the following describes a warm occlusion?

options.text: The coldest air mass is ahead of the original warm front.
The air mass ahead of the front is drier than the air mass behind the front.
The air mass behind the front is more unstable than the air mass ahead of the front.
The warmer air mass is ahead of the original warm front.

variant.question: Which of the following describes a warm occlusion?

front

A night in January has been cold and clear. In the forenoon of the next day an airfield is in IMC due to fog which extends to a height of 700 ft. A heavily laden aircraft departs and, when breaking through the top of the fog, experiences temporary bumpiness and a sudden decrease in climb rate. Mark the answer that states the most probable reason for the altered aircraft performance.

options.text: The aircraft suffers reduced lift and thrust due to a temperature inversion at the top of the fog.
The additional weight gained by water which has been gathered on wings and fuselage during flight through the fog reduces the lift.
The aircraft is under influence of a mountain breeze (descending air from the surrounding hills due to the incident sunshine).
The water which has been gathered during flight through the fog modifies the aerodynamic properties of the aircraft, thus reducing lift.

The term CAVOK is used when weather conditions are:
The term CAVOK is used when weather conditions are:
Which one of the following alternatives indicates how an occluded front is generated?

options.text: A cold front overtakes a warm front and the warm air between the fronts is lifted.
A cold front is halted and becomes almost stationary.
Cold air wedges under warm air.

variant.question: Which of the following conditions must be met if weather conditions are reported as "CAVOK"?

options.text: No clouds below the highest minimum sector altitude.
Wind speed of less than 15 kts.
Wind speed of less than 25 kts.
No clouds are present below 8 000 ft AGL.
